msgSnippet: ... It should be a mix of both. Developers provide white box testing (testing with knowledge of the implementation) and simple tests of all the main features
messageBody:
On 1/20/06, hdpoliya <haod@...> wrote:
>
> But to my knowlege, your experience is against the theory of software
> engineering. We suggest that during developing, the testers of a
> program should not be the ones developed it.
> I am confused.


It should be a mix of both.

Developers provide white box testing (testing with knowledge of the
implementation) and simple tests of all the main features they code.

QA testers provide black box testing. They are given functional specs and
the tests of the developers and they write their own tests from there.

The reason why you can't let either group own 100% of the tests is because
they each come with their own bias/limitations:

- Developers tend to test only what they think their software does.
- QA testers can overlook testing tricky parts of the code because
either the functional specs or their understanding of the code is not
exhaustive.
